## [tag/NFS-Actions](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/NFS-Actions) NFS Actions\
\
NFS actions are tasks that can be executed on an NFS share. These can be\
things like resizing, snapshotting, etc.\
\
## [tag/NFS-Actions/operation/nfs_create_action](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/NFS-Actions/operation/nfs_create_action) Initiate an NFS action\
\
To execute an action (such as resize) on a specified NFS share,\
send a POST request to `/v2/nfs/{nfs_id}/actions`. In the JSON body\
to the request, set the `type` attribute to on of the supported action types:\
\
| Action | Details |\
| --- | --- |\
| `resize` | Resizes an NFS share. Set the size\_gib attribute to a desired value in GiB |\
| `snapshot` | Takes a snapshot of an NFS share |\
| `attach` | Attaches an NFS share to a VPC. Set the vpc\_id attribute to the desired VPC ID |\
| `detach` | Detaches an NFS share from a VPC. Set the vpc\_id attribute to the desired VPC ID |\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### path Parameters\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| nfs\_id<br>required | string<br>Example: 0a1b2c3d-4e5f-6a7b-8c9d-0e1f2a3b4c5d<br>The unique ID of the NFS share |\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json  required\
\
The `type` attribute set in the request body will specify the action that\
will be taken on the NFS share. Some actions will require additional\
attributes to be set as well.\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| type<br>required | string<br>The type of action to initiate for the NFS share (such as resize or snapshot).<br>detachattachresizesnapshotresize |\
| region<br>required | string<br>The DigitalOcean region slug (e.g. atl1, nyc2) where the NFS snapshot resides. |\
| params | object |\
\
### Responses\
\
**201**\
\
The response will be a JSON object with a key called `action`.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**404**\
\
The resource was not found.\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\
There was a server error.\
\
**default**\
\
There was an unexpected error.\
\
post/v2/nfs/{nfs\_id}/actions\
\
production\
\

## [tag/Partner-Network-Connect/operation/partnerAttachments_create](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Partner-Network-Connect/operation/partnerAttachments_create) Create a new partner attachment\
\
To create a new partner attachment, send a `POST` request to\
`/v2/partner_network_connect/attachments` with a JSON object containing the\
required configuration details.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| name<br>required | string^\[a-zA-Z0-9\\-\\.\]+$<br>The name of the partner attachment. Must be unique and may only contain alphanumeric characters, dashes, and periods. |\
| connection\_bandwidth\_in\_mbps<br>required | integer<br>Enum:10002000500010000<br>Bandwidth (in Mbps) of the connection. |\
| region<br>required | string<br>Enum:"nyc""sfo""fra""ams""sgp"<br>The region to create the partner attachment. |\
| naas\_provider<br>required | string |\
| vpc\_ids<br>required | Array of strings <string>  non-empty \[ items <string > \]<br>An array of VPCs IDs. |\
| parent\_uuid | string<br>Optional associated partner attachment UUID |\
| bgp | object<br>Optional BGP configurations |\
| redundancy\_zone | string<br>Enum:"MEGAPORT\_BLUE""MEGAPORT\_RED"<br>Optional redundancy zone for the partner attachment. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**202**\
\
The response will be a JSON object with details about the partner attachment\
including attached VPC network IDs and BGP configuration information\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**404**\
\

## [tag/Project-Resources](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Project-Resources) Project Resources\
\
Project Resources are resources that can be grouped into your projects.\
You can group resources (like Droplets, Spaces, load balancers, domains,\
and floating IPs) in ways that align with the applications you host on\
DigitalOcean.\
\
### Supported Resource Types Examples\
\
Projects resources are identified by uniform resource names or URNs. A\
valid URN has the following format: `do:resource_type:resource_id`. The\
following resource types are supported:\
\
| Resource Type | Example URN |\
| --- | --- |\
| App Platform App | `do:app:be5aab85-851b-4cab-b2ed-98d5a63ba4e8` |\
| Database | `do:dbaas:83c7a55f-0d84-4760-9245-aba076ec2fb2` |\
| Domain | `do:domain:example.com` |\
| Droplet | `do:droplet:4126873` |\
| Floating IP | `do:floatingip:192.168.99.100` |\
| Kubernetes Cluster | `do:kubernetes:bd5f5959-5e1e-4205-a714-a914373942af` |\
| Load Balancer | `do:loadbalancer:39052d89-8dd4-4d49-8d5a-3c3b6b365b5b` |\
| Space | `do:space:my-website-assets` |\
| Volume | `do:volume:6fc4c277-ea5c-448a-93cd-dd496cfef71f` |\
\
### Resource Status Codes\
\
When assigning and retrieving resources in projects, a `status` attribute\
is returned that indicates if a resource was successfully retrieved or\
assigned. The status codes can be one of the following:\
\
| Status Code | Explanation |\
| --- | --- |\
| `ok` | There was no problem retrieving or assigning a resource. |\
| `not_found` | The resource was not found. |\
| `assigned` | The resource was successfully assigned. |\
| `already_assigned` | The resource was already assigned. |\
| `service_down` | There was a problem retrieving or assigning a resource. Please try again. |\
\
## [tag/Project-Resources/operation/projects_list_resources](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Project-Resources/operation/projects_list_resources) List Project Resources\
\
To list all your resources in a project, send a GET request to `/v2/projects/$PROJECT_ID/resources`.\
\
This endpoint will only return resources that you are authorized to see. For example, to see Droplets in a project, include the `droplet:read` scope.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\

\
##### query Parameters\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| per\_page | integer \[ 1 .. 200 \] <br>Default: 20<br>Example: per\_page=2<br>Number of items returned per page |\
| page | integer >= 1 <br>Default: 1<br>Example: page=1<br>Which 'page' of paginated results to return. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**200**\
\
The response will be a JSON object with a key called `resources`.\
The value of this will be an object with the standard resource attributes.\
\
Only resources that you are authorized to see will be returned.\
\

\

\

\

\

\

\

\
**default**\
\

## [tag/Project-Resources/operation/projects_assign_resources](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Project-Resources/operation/projects_assign_resources) Assign Resources to a Project\
\
To assign resources to a project, send a POST request to `/v2/projects/$PROJECT_ID/resources`.\
\
You must have both `project:update` and `<resource>:read` scopes to assign new resources. For example, to assign a Droplet to a project, include both the `project:update` and `droplet:read` scopes.\
\

\
_bearer\_auth_\

\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| resources | Array of strings (urn) \[ items^do:(dbaas\|domain\|droplet\|floatingip\|loadbala...Show pattern \]<br>A list of uniform resource names (URNs) to be added to a project. Only resources that you are authorized to see will be returned. |\

## [tag/Projects](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Projects) Projects\
\
Projects allow you to organize your resources into groups that fit the way\
you work. You can group resources (like Droplets, Spaces, load balancers,\
domains, and floating IPs) in ways that align with the applications\
you host on DigitalOcean.\

## [tag/Projects/operation/projects_delete](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Projects/operation/projects_delete) Delete an Existing Project\
\
To delete a project, send a DELETE request to `/v2/projects/$PROJECT_ID`. To\
be deleted, a project must not have any resources assigned to it. Any existing\
resources must first be reassigned or destroyed, or you will receive a 412 error.\
\
A successful request will receive a 204 status code with no body in response.\
This indicates that the request was processed successfully.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### path Parameters\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| project\_id<br>required | string <uuid>  >= 1 <br>Example: 4de7ac8b-495b-4884-9a69-1050c6793cd6<br>A unique identifier for a project. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**204**\
\
The action was successful and the response body is empty.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**404**\
\
The resource was not found.\
\
**412**\
\
Only an empty project can be deleted.\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\
There was a server error.\
\
**default**\
\
There was an unexpected error.\
\
delete/v2/projects/{project\_id}\
\
production\
\
https://api.digitalocean.com/v2/projects/{project\_id}\
\

\
- cURL\
- Go\
- Ruby\

\

curl -X DELETE -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H "Authorization: Bearer $DIGITALOCEAN_TOKEN" \\
  "https://api.digitalocean.com/v2/projects/4e1bfbc3-dc3e-41f2-a18f-1b4d7ba71679"\

## [tag/Reserved-IP-Actions](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Reserved-IP-Actions) Reserved IP Actions\
\
As of 16 June 2022, we have renamed the [Floating IP](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/api-reference/#tag/Floating-IPs)\
product to Reserved IPs. The Reserved IP product's endpoints function the exact\
same way as Floating IPs. The only difference is the name change throughout the\
URLs and fields. For example, the `floating_ips` field is now the `reserved_ips` field.\
The Floating IP endpoints will remain active until fall 2023 before being\
permanently deprecated.\
\
With the exception of the [Projects API](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/api-reference/#tag/Projects),\
we will reflect this change as an additional field in the responses across the API\
where the `floating_ip` field is used. For example, the Droplet metadata response\
will contain the field `reserved_ips` in addition to the `floating_ips` field.\
Floating IPs retrieved using the Projects API will retain the original name.\
\
Reserved IP actions are commands that can be given to a DigitalOcean\
reserved IP. These requests are made on the actions endpoint of a specific\
reserved IP.\
\
An action object is returned. These objects hold the current status of the\
requested action.\
\
## [tag/Reserved-IP-Actions/operation/reservedIPsActions_list](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Reserved-IP-Actions/operation/reservedIPsActions_list) List All Actions for a Reserved IP\

## [tag/Reserved-IP-Actions/operation/reservedIPsActions_post](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Reserved-IP-Actions/operation/reservedIPsActions_post) Initiate a Reserved IP Action\
\
To initiate an action on a reserved IP send a POST request to\
`/v2/reserved_ips/$RESERVED_IP/actions`. In the JSON body to the request,\
set the `type` attribute to on of the supported action types:\
\
| Action | Details |\
| --- | --- |\
| `assign` | Assigns a reserved IP to a Droplet |\
| `unassign` | Unassign a reserved IP from a Droplet |\

| --- | --- |\
| reserved\_ip<br>required | string <ipv4>  >= 1 <br>Example: 45.55.96.47<br>A reserved IP address. |\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json\
\
The `type` attribute set in the request body will specify the action that\
will be taken on the reserved IP.\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| type<br>required | string<br>The type of action to initiate for the reserved IP.<br>assignunassignunassign |\

The response will be an object with a key called `action`. The value of this will be an object that contains the standard reserved IP action attributes.\

## [tag/Reserved-IPs](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Reserved-IPs) Reserved IPs\
\
As of 16 June 2022, we have renamed the [Floating IP](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/api-reference/#tag/Floating-IPs)\
product to Reserved IPs. The Reserved IP product's endpoints function the exact\
same way as Floating IPs. The only difference is the name change throughout the\
URLs and fields. For example, the `floating_ips` field is now the `reserved_ips` field.\
The Floating IP endpoints will remain active until fall 2023 before being\
permanently deprecated.\
\
With the exception of the [Projects API](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/api-reference/#tag/Projects),\
we will reflect this change as an additional field in the responses across the API\
where the `floating_ip` field is used. For example, the Droplet metadata response\
will contain the field `reserved_ips` in addition to the `floating_ips` field.\
Floating IPs retrieved using the Projects API will retain the original name.\
\
DigitalOcean Reserved IPs are publicly-accessible static IP addresses that can be\
mapped to one of your Droplets. They can be used to create highly available\
setups or other configurations requiring movable addresses.\
\
Reserved IPs are bound to a specific region.\
\

## [tag/Reserved-IPs/operation/reservedIPs_create](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Reserved-IPs/operation/reservedIPs_create) Create a New Reserved IP\
\
On creation, a reserved IP must be either assigned to a Droplet or reserved to a region.\
\
- To create a new reserved IP assigned to a Droplet, send a POST\
request to `/v2/reserved_ips` with the `droplet_id` attribute.\
\
- To create a new reserved IP reserved to a region, send a POST request to\
`/v2/reserved_ips` with the `region` attribute.\
\
\

\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json  required\
\
One of\
\
Assign to DropletReserve to Region\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| droplet\_id<br>required | integer<br>The ID of the Droplet that the reserved IP will be assigned to. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**202**\
\
The response will be a JSON object with a key called `reserved_ip`. The value of this will be an object that contains the standard attributes associated with a reserved IP.\
When assigning a reserved IP to a Droplet at same time as it created, the response's `links` object will contain links to both the Droplet and the assignment action. The latter can be used to check the status of the action.\

Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\

## [tag/Reserved-IPv6-Actions](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Reserved-IPv6-Actions) Reserved IPv6 Actions\
\
Reserved IPv6 actions requests are made on the actions endpoint of a specific\
reserved IPv6.\
\
An action object is returned. These objects hold the current status of the\
requested action.\
\
## [tag/Reserved-IPv6-Actions/operation/reservedIPv6Actions_post](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Reserved-IPv6-Actions/operation/reservedIPv6Actions_post) Initiate a Reserved IPv6 Action\
\
To initiate an action on a reserved IPv6 send a POST request to\
`/v2/reserved_ipv6/$RESERVED_IPV6/actions`. In the JSON body to the request,\
set the `type` attribute to on of the supported action types:\
\
| Action | Details |\
| --- | --- |\
| `assign` | Assigns a reserved IPv6 to a Droplet |\
| `unassign` | Unassign a reserved IPv6 from a Droplet |\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### path Parameters\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| reserved\_ipv6<br>required | string <ipv6>  >= 1 <br>Example: 2409:40d0:f7:1017:74b4:3a96:105e:4c6e<br>A reserved IPv6 address. |\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json\
\
The `type` attribute set in the request body will specify the action that\
will be taken on the reserved IPv6.\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| type<br>required | string<br>The type of action to initiate for the reserved IPv6.<br>assignunassignunassign |\
\
### Responses\
\
**201**\
\
The response will be an object with a key called `action`. The value of this will be an object that contains the standard reserved IP action attributes.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**404**\
\
The resource was not found.\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\
There was a server error.\
\
**default**\
\
There was an unexpected error.\
\
post/v2/reserved\_ipv6/{reserved\_ipv6}/actions\

## [tag/BYOIP-Prefixes](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/BYOIP-Prefixes) BYOIP Prefixes\
\
Bring your own IP (BYOIP) lets you provision your own IPv4 network prefixes\
to your account, then assign those IPs to your DigitalOcean resources.\
BYOIP supports the following features:\
\
- IPv4 addresses\
- Network sizes of anywhere from `/24` (256 addresses) to `/18` (16,384 addresses)\
- Same API and management interface as our existing reserved IPs feature\
- Assignable to Droplets only\
\
## [tag/BYOIP-Prefixes/operation/byoipPrefixes_create](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/BYOIP-Prefixes/operation/byoipPrefixes_create) Create a BYOIP Prefix\
\
To create a BYOIP prefix, send a POST request to `/v2/byoip_prefixes`.\
\
A successful request will initiate the process of bringing your BYOIP Prefix into your account.\
The response will include the details of the created prefix, including its UUID and status.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json  required\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| prefix<br>required | string<br>The IP prefix in CIDR notation to bring |\
| region<br>required | string<br>The region where the prefix will be created |\
| signature<br>required | string<br>The signature hash for the prefix creation request |\
\
### Responses\
\
**202**\
\
BYOIP prefix request accepted, response will contain the details of the created prefix.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**422**\
\
Unprocessable Entity\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\
There was a server error.\
\
**default**\
\
There was an unexpected error.\
\

## [tag/Sizes](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Sizes) Sizes\
\
The sizes objects represent different packages of hardware resources that\
can be used for Droplets. When a Droplet is created, a size must be\
selected so that the correct resources can be allocated.\
\
Each size represents a plan that bundles together specific sets of\
resources. This includes the amount of RAM, the number of virtual CPUs,\
disk space, and transfer. The size object also includes the pricing\
details and the regions that the size is available in.\
\
## [tag/Sizes/operation/sizes_list](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Sizes/operation/sizes_list) List All Droplet Sizes\
\

The response will be a JSON object with a key called `sizes`. The value of this will be an array of `size` objects each of which contain the standard size attributes.\

\
### Responses\

**200**\
\
A JSON object with a key called `sizes`. The value of this will be an array of `size` objects each of which contain the standard size attributes.\

\

## [tag/Snapshots](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Snapshots) Snapshots\
\
[Snapshots](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/snapshots/) are saved\
instances of a Droplet or a block storage volume, which is reflected in\
the `resource_type` attribute. In order to avoid problems with compressing\
filesystems, each defines a `min_disk_size` attribute which is the minimum\
size of the Droplet or volume disk when creating a new resource from the\
saved snapshot.\
\
To interact with snapshots, you will generally send requests to the\
snapshots endpoint at `/v2/snapshots`.\
\
## [tag/Snapshots/operation/snapshots_list](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Snapshots/operation/snapshots_list) List All Snapshots\
\
To list all of the snapshots available on your account, send a GET request to\
`/v2/snapshots`.\
\
The response will be a JSON object with a key called `snapshots`. This will be\
set to an array of `snapshot` objects, each of which will contain the standard\
snapshot attributes.\
\
### Filtering Results by Resource Type\
\
It's possible to request filtered results by including certain query parameters.\
\
#### List Droplet Snapshots\
\
To retrieve only snapshots based on Droplets, include the `resource_type`\
query parameter set to `droplet`. For example, `/v2/snapshots?resource_type=droplet`.\
\
#### List Volume Snapshots\
\
To retrieve only snapshots based on volumes, include the `resource_type`\
query parameter set to `volume`. For example, `/v2/snapshots?resource_type=volume`.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### query Parameters\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| per\_page | integer \[ 1 .. 200 \] <br>Default: 20<br>Example: per\_page=2<br>Number of items returned per page |\
| page | integer >= 1 <br>Default: 1<br>Example: page=1<br>Which 'page' of paginated results to return. |\
| resource\_type | string<br>Enum:"droplet""volume"<br>Example: resource\_type=droplet<br>Used to filter snapshots by a resource type. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**200**\
\
A JSON object with a key of `snapshots`.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\
There was a server error.\
\
**default**\
\
There was an unexpected error.\
\
get/v2/snapshots\
\
production\
\
https://api.digitalocean.com/v2/snapshots\
\

  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \\
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $DIGITALOCEAN_TOKEN" \\

## [tag/Spaces-Keys](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Spaces-Keys) Spaces Keys\
\
Spaces keys authenticate requests to DigitalOcean Spaces Buckets.\
You can create, list, update, or delete Spaces keys by sending requests to\
to the `/v2/spaces/keys` endpoint.\
\
## [tag/Spaces-Keys/operation/spacesKey_list](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Spaces-Keys/operation/spacesKey_list) List Spaces Access Keys\
\

\

| bucket | string<br>Example: bucket=my-bucket<br>The bucket's name. |\

## [tag/Tags](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Tags) Tags\
\
A tag is a label that can be applied to a resource (currently Droplets,\
Images, Volumes, Volume Snapshots, and Database clusters) in order to\
better organize or facilitate the lookups and actions on it.\
\
Tags have two attributes: a user defined `name` attribute and an embedded\
`resources` attribute with information about resources that have been tagged.\
\
## [tag/Tags/operation/tags_list](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Tags/operation/tags_list) List All Tags\
\
To list all of your tags, you can send a GET request to `/v2/tags`.\
\
This endpoint will only return tagged resources that you are authorized to see\
(e.g. Droplets will only be returned if you have `droplet:read`).\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### query Parameters\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| per\_page | integer \[ 1 .. 200 \] <br>Default: 20<br>Example: per\_page=2<br>Number of items returned per page |\
| page | integer >= 1 <br>Default: 1<br>Example: page=1<br>Which 'page' of paginated results to return. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**200**\
\
To list all of your tags, you can send a `GET` request to `/v2/tags`.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\

\
**default**\
\

## [tag/Tags/operation/tags_create](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Tags/operation/tags_create) Create a New Tag\
\
To create a tag you can send a POST request to `/v2/tags` with a `name` attribute.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json  required\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\

Tags may contain letters, numbers, colons, dashes, and underscores.<br>There is a limit of 255 characters per tag.<br>**Note:** Tag names are case stable, which means the capitalization you use when you first create a tag is canonical.<br>When working with tags in the API, you must use the tag's canonical capitalization. ## [tag/Tags/operation/tags_assign_resources](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Tags/operation/tags_assign_resources) Tag a Resource\
\
Resources can be tagged by sending a POST request to\
`/v2/tags/$TAG_NAME/resources` with an array of json objects containing\
`resource_id` and `resource_type` attributes.\
\
Currently only tagging of Droplets, Databases, Images, Volumes, and Volume\

to tag a Droplet, you must have `tag:create` and `droplet:update`.\

## [tag/Uptime](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Uptime) Uptime\
\
[DigitalOcean Uptime Checks](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/uptime/) provide the ability to monitor your endpoints from around the world, and alert you when they're slow, unavailable, or SSL certificates are expiring.\
To interact with Uptime, you will generally send requests to the Uptime endpoint at `/v2/uptime/`.\
\

## [tag/Uptime/operation/uptime_create_alert](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/Uptime/operation/uptime_create_alert) Create a New Alert\
\
To create an Uptime alert, send a POST request to `/v2/uptime/checks/$CHECK_ID/alerts` specifying the attributes\
in the table below in the JSON body.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### path Parameters\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| check\_id<br>required | string <uuid> <br>Example: 4de7ac8b-495b-4884-9a69-1050c6793cd6<br>A unique identifier for a check. |\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json  required\
\
The ''type'' field dictates the type of alert, and hence what type of value to pass into the threshold property.\
\
| Type | Description | Threshold Value |\
| --- | --- | --- |\
| `latency` | alerts on the response latency | milliseconds |\
| `down` | alerts on a target registering as down in any region | N/A (Not required) |\
| `down_global` | alerts on a target registering as down globally | N/A (Not required) |\
| `ssl_expiry` | alerts on a SSL certificate expiring within $threshold days | days |\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| name<br>required | string<br>A human-friendly display name. |\
| type<br>required | string<br>Enum:"latency""down""down\_global""ssl\_expiry"<br>The type of alert. |\
| threshold | integer<br>The threshold at which the alert will enter a trigger state. The specific threshold is dependent on the alert type. |\
| comparison | string<br>Enum:"greater\_than""less\_than"<br>The comparison operator used against the alert's threshold. |\
| notifications<br>required | object (notification) <br>The notification settings for a trigger alert. |\
| period<br>required | string<br>Enum:"2m""3m""5m""10m""15m""30m""1h"<br>Period of time the threshold must be exceeded to trigger the alert. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**201**\
\
The response will be a JSON object with a key called `alert`. The value of this will be an object that contains the standard attributes associated with an uptime alert.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**404**\
\
The resource was not found.\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\
There was a server error.\
\
**default**\
\
There was an unexpected error.\
\

## [tag/VPC-NAT-Gateways](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPC-NAT-Gateways) VPC NAT Gateways\
\
[VPC NAT Gateways](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/networking/vpc/how-to/create-nat-gateway/)\
allow resources in a private VPC to access the public internet without\
exposing them to incoming traffic.\
\
By sending requests to the `/v2/vpc_nat_gateways` endpoint, you can create,\
configure, list, and delete VPC NAT Gateways as well as retrieve information\
about the resources assigned to them.\
\
## [tag/VPC-NAT-Gateways/operation/vpcnatgateways_list](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPC-NAT-Gateways/operation/vpcnatgateways_list) List All VPC NAT Gateways\

## [tag/VPC-Peerings](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPC-Peerings) VPC Peerings\
\
[VPC Peerings](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/networking/vpc/how-to/create-peering/)\
join two VPC networks with a secure, private connection. This allows\
resources in those networks to connect to each other's private IP addresses\
as if they were in the same network.\
\

\
To create a new VPC Peering, send a POST request to `/v2/vpc_peerings`\
specifying a name and a list of two VPC IDs to peer. The response code, 202\
Accepted, does not indicate the success or failure of the operation, just\

| vpc\_ids<br>required | Array of strings <uuid>  = 2 items \[ items <uuid > \]<br>An array of the two peered VPCs IDs. |\

## [tag/VPCs](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPCs) VPCs\
\
[VPCs (virtual private clouds)](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/networking/vpc/)\
allow you to create virtual networks containing resources that can\
communicate with each other in full isolation using private IP addresses.\
\
By sending requests to the `/v2/vpcs` endpoint, you can create, configure,\
list, and delete custom VPCs as well as retrieve information about the\
resources assigned to them.\
\

## [tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_create](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_create) Create a New VPC\
\
To create a VPC, send a POST request to `/v2/vpcs` specifying the attributes\
in the table below in the JSON body.\
\
**Note:** If you do not currently have a VPC network in a specific datacenter\
region, the first one that you create will be set as the default for that\
region. The default VPC for a region cannot be changed or deleted.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json  required\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| name<br>required | string^\[a-zA-Z0-9\\-\\.\]+$<br>The name of the VPC. Must be unique and may only contain alphanumeric characters, dashes, and periods. |\
| description | string <= 255 characters <br>A free-form text field for describing the VPC's purpose. It may be a maximum of 255 characters. |\
| region<br>required | string<br>The slug identifier for the region where the VPC will be created. |\
| ip\_range | string<br>The range of IP addresses in the VPC in CIDR notation. Network ranges cannot overlap with other networks in the same account and must be in range of private addresses as defined in RFC1918. It may not be smaller than `/28` nor larger than `/16`. If no IP range is specified, a `/20` network range is generated that won't conflict with other VPC networks in your account. |\
\
### Responses\
\
**201**\
\
The response will be a JSON object with a key called `vpc`. The value of this will be an object that contains the standard attributes associated with a VPC.\
\
**401**\
\
Authentication failed due to invalid credentials.\
\
**429**\
\
The API rate limit has been exceeded.\
\
**500**\
\
There was a server error.\
\
**default**\
\
There was an unexpected error.\

## [tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_delete](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_delete) Delete a VPC\
\
To delete a VPC, send a DELETE request to `/v2/vpcs/$VPC_ID`. A 204 status\
code with no body will be returned in response to a successful request.\
\
The default VPC for a region can not be deleted. Additionally, a VPC can only\
be deleted if it does not contain any member resources. Attempting to delete\
a region's default VPC or a VPC that still has members will result in a\
403 Forbidden error response.\

## [tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_list_members](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_list_members) List the Member Resources of a VPC\
\
To list all of the resources that are members of a VPC, send a GET request to\
`/v2/vpcs/$VPC_ID/members`.\

To only list resources of a specific type that are members of the VPC,\

in the VPC, send a GET request to `/v2/vpcs/$VPC_ID/members?resource_type=droplet`.\

you must have `droplet:read`).\

## [tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_create_peerings](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_create_peerings) Create a Peering with a VPC\
\
To create a new VPC peering for a given VPC, send a POST request to\
`/v2/vpcs/$VPC_ID/peerings`.\
\
##### Authorizations:\
\
_bearer\_auth_\
\
##### path Parameters\
\
|     |     |\

\

| vpc\_id<br>required | string <uuid> <br>The ID of the VPC to peer with. |\

## [tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_patch_peerings](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/digitalocean//\#tag/VPCs/operation/vpcs_patch_peerings) Update a VPC Peering\
\
To update the name of a VPC peering in a particular VPC, send a PATCH request\
to `/v2/vpcs/$VPC_ID/peerings/$VPC_PEERING_ID` with the new `name` in the\
request body.\

##### Authorizations:\

\
##### path Parameters\
\

| --- | --- |\
| vpc\_id<br>required | string <uuid>  >= 1 <br>Example: 4de7ac8b-495b-4884-9a69-1050c6793cd6<br>A unique identifier for a VPC. |\
| vpc\_peering\_id<br>required | string <uuid> <br>Example: 5a4981aa-9653-4bd1-bef5-d6bff52042e4<br>A unique identifier for a VPC peering. |\
\
##### Request Body schema: application/json  required\
\
|     |     |\
| --- | --- |\
| name<br>required | string^\[a-zA-Z0-9\\-\]+$<br>The name of the VPC peering. Must be unique within the team and may only contain alphanumeric characters and dashes. |\
\
### Responses\

**200**\
\
